messages.text: It should automatically detect a project.toml file in the working directory. If not, you can click on the Julia environment tab on the bottom and set it to the path you want. Or else I think there’s an option you can set in the directory .vscode/settings.json (you can make one of these if it isn’t already there)

messages.text: That's because we don't start the REPL through your shell. I think your way should work fine if you start VSCode from bash though. Otherwise use the `terminal.integrated.env.linux` setting (or whatever OS you're on).

messages.text:
Do you mean a Python virtualenv?
```ENV["PYCALL_JL_RUNTIME_PYTHON"] =  pwd() * "/bin/python3"

using PyCall

torch = pyimport("torch")```
Posting in the hopes someone will correct me if there's a better way.

root.text: Hey everyone, apologies if this is answered somewhere. Is there a way to set up vscode to work with a virtual environment? I assume there's a json config file somewhere, but I'm not finding the details online.

elements.text: Hey everyone, apologies if this is answered somewhere. Is there a way to set up vscode to work with a virtual environment? I assume there's a json config file somewhere, but I'm not finding the details online.
Do you mean a Python virtualenv?

ENV["PYCALL_JL_RUNTIME_PYTHON"] =  pwd() * "/bin/python3"

using PyCall

torch = pyimport("torch")
Posting in the hopes someone will correct me if there's a better way.

messages.text: Hey folks, I am new to vscode and the julia extension as well. I was just following along in the video tutorial from a few months ago, and I realize that I don't seem to get the inline showing of the code results. So I write a line of code like `cars = dataset("cars")`, and I run that line of code, in my case `ctrl+c ctrl+j` because I set the key binding. I see the dataframe in the repl window, but not next to the actual line of code. Also if I hover over the line of code, I don't see any variable results, etc. Did I set something up wrong or is there someway to enable that setting?

 [1] hook_repl(repl::REPL.LineEditREPL)
   @ VSCodeServer ~/.vscode-server/extensions/julialang.language-julia-1.1.27/scripts/packages/VSCodeServer/src/repl.jl:70
 [2] (::VSCodeServer.var"#2#4"{REPL.LineEditREPL})()
   @ VSCodeServer ./task.jl:406
[ Info: loading Revise```
I've got the same startup I've had for ages, is there some change needed now?

```atreplinit() do repl
    @info "Loading OhMyREPL"
    @eval using OhMyREPL

    try
        @info "loading Revise"
        @eval using Revise
        @async Revise.wait_steal_repl_backend()
    catch e
        @warn("unable to load Revise", e)
    end
end```
This is julia 1.6-rc1

messages.text:
I am getting an error that only happens in the REPL spawned by VSCode, not in the usual REPL. I am trying out some Luxor.jl code to create animations. This one, for instance:
```# Adapted from [Cormullian's Slackmojiv's post](<https://cormullion.github.io/pages/2019-06-23-slackmojif/>)
using Luxor

function frame(scene, framenumber)
    nfn = rescale(framenumber, scene.framerange.start, scene.framerange.stop)
    rotate(π*sin(nfn * 2π))
    juliacircles(18)
end

size = 64
mymovie = Movie(size, size, "mymovie")
animate(mymovie, [Scene(mymovie, frame, 1:60)],
    creategif=true, pathname="juliafullrocker$(size)x$(size).gif")```
In the REPL, there is no problem, and the animated gif is created. But when I run it from inside vscode, I get the error
```┌ Info: Frames for animation "mymovie" are being stored in directory: 
└        /var/folders/yj/2q95f5rd57n7_6_q2jym158w0000gn/T/jl_zbLIzB
┌ Warning: Movie framerange is longer than scene frame range: 
│        1:250 > 60
└ @ Luxor ~/.julia/packages/Luxor/XSNgj/src/animate.jl:185
┌ Info: ... 60 frames saved in directory:
└        /var/folders/yj/2q95f5rd57n7_6_q2jym158w0000gn/T/jl_zbLIzB
ERROR: LoadError: IOError: could not spawn `ffmpeg -loglevel panic -framerate 30 -f image2 -i /var/folders/yj/2q95f5rd57n7_6_q2jym158w0000gn/T/jl_zbLIzB/%10d.png -filter_complex '[0:v] split [a][b]; [a] palettegen=stats_mode=full:reserve_transparent=on:transparency_color=FFFFFF [p]; [b][p] paletteuse=new=1:alpha_threshold=128' -y /var/folders/yj/2q95f5rd57n7_6_q2jym158w0000gn/T/jl_zbLIzB/mymovie.gif`: no such file or directory (ENOENT)
Stacktrace:
 [1] _spawn_primitive(::String, ::Cmd, ::Array{Any,1}) at ./process.jl:99
 [2] #585 at ./process.jl:112 [inlined]
 [3] setup_stdios(::Base.var"#585#586"{Cmd}, ::Array{Any,1}) at ./process.jl:196
 [4] _spawn at ./process.jl:111 [inlined]
 [5] run(::Cmd; wait::Bool) at ./process.jl:439
 [6] run at ./process.jl:438 [inlined]
 [7] animate(::Movie, ::Array{Scene,1}; creategif::Bool, framerate::Int64, pathname::String, tempdirectory::String, usenewffmpeg::Bool) at /Users/rrosa/.julia/packages/Luxor/XSNgj/src/animate.jl:211
 [8] top-level scope at /Users/rrosa/Documents/git_repositories/julia/julia_random_stuff/src/julia_rocker.jl:16
in expression starting at /Users/rrosa/Documents/git_repositories/julia/julia_random_stuff/src/julia_rocker.jl:16```
When I copy the ffmpeg command and run it directly in the shell, it works too.

Is that due to how the VSCode Julia extension handles this or is it something else?

messages.text: I figured (with a little help from friends), that the problem with vscode/Luxor is a PATH thing. The REPL that vscode/julia extension spawns when I run the code doesn’t have the PATH environmental variable set. How can I make the extension pick up the PATH variable set by the shell?
